docs.snippet: The Devils face great uncertainty with their All-Star goalie Martin Brodeur out with an injury....
docs.lead_paragraph: Martin Brodeur will have surgery Thursday to repair a torn bicep muscle in his left arm, the first major injury of his career, and will miss three to four months for the New Jersey Devils.
docs.abstract: The Devils face great uncertainty with their All-Star goalie Martin Brodeur out with an injury.

headline.main: The Morning Skate: Brodeur Out at Least Three Months

docs.snippet: Can the next president make the "moon shot" case for climate and energy action?...

Mr. Magaziner (below) appears to have been right.]

docs.snippet: Last week, at the giant American base in Baghdad called Camp Liberty, I asked a U.S. Army captain what he thought about the elections. Was he excited about them or about one of the candidates? His answer took me aback....
docs.lead_paragraph: Wesley Morgan is a research assistant studying American military operations in Iraq, and is currently based at The New York Times's Baghdad Bureau. He is an undergraduate student at Princeton University.
docs.abstract: Last week, at the giant American base in Baghdad called Camp Liberty, I asked a U.S. Army captain what he thought about the elections. Was he excited about them or about one of the candidates? His answer took me aback.

docs.snippet: The day of a riveting national election may present a public relations opportunity for anyone with an unfavorable or embarrassing story they have to tell, but hope to bury....
docs.lead_paragraph: As millions of Americans head to the polls today to choose a new president, reporters across the country and around the world will have their attention trained largely on the election. It will be a busy day for journalists - and perhaps, if history is any indication, a good day to sneak out some bad news under the radar.
docs.abstract: The day of a riveting national election may present a public relations opportunity for anyone with an unfavorable or embarrassing story they have to tell, but hope to bury.

headline.main: Days When News Can Go Unnoticed

docs.snippet: A second investigation into whether Gov. Sarah Palin abused the powers of her office to pursue a personal vendetta has found ''no probable cause'' to believe she violated an Alaska ethics law by trying to get her former brother-in-law, a state tro...
docs.lead_paragraph: A second investigation into whether Gov. Sarah Palin abused the powers of her office to pursue a personal vendetta has found ''no probable cause'' to believe she violated an Alaska ethics law by trying to get her former brother-in-law, a state trooper, fired or by actually dismissing the state's public safety commission, who was the trooper's boss. The conclusion by an independent investigator for the state Personnel Board contradicts a determination last month of an inquiry by the Alaska Legislature that Ms. Palin had breached the ethics act by pressing to have the trooper, Michael Wooten, dismissed. That investigation found, however, that the governor was within her right to fire her public safety commissioner, Walt Monegan.
docs.abstract: Alaska Personnel Board releases report that finds Gov Sarah Palin did not apply improper pressure in trying to dismiss state trooper who was her former brother-in-law Mike Wooten and did not violate state ethics laws in firing of her public safety commissioner; report contradicts conclusions of separate inquiry into matter overseen by bipartisan legislative panel, which found that Palin breached state ethics law by pressing to have Wooten fired; report contends that legislative inquiry based its conclusions on incorrect intepretation of state law and on insufficient evidence; photo (M)

headline.main: Independent Counsel Clears Palin of Ethics Violations

byline.original: By SERGE F. KOVALESKI; William Yardley contributed reporting from Anchorage

docs.snippet: Interviews with voters at the polls indicated that Representative Charles B. Rangel's constituents are likely to re-elect him and are paying little heed to a controversy over his personal housing arrangement and finances....
docs.lead_paragraph: The results of many contests in today's election are anything but predictable, but there seems to be one safe bet, and that's in the race for Congress in northern Manhattan: Representative Charles B. Rangel is certain to win a 20th term in Congress.
docs.abstract: Interviews with voters at the polls indicated that Representative Charles B. Rangel's constituents are likely to re-elect him and are paying little heed to a controversy over his personal housing arrangement and finances.

headline.main: Rangel, House Veteran, Retains Strong Support
